Award.AwardTitle: Formation, Growth and Separation of the Northwest Corner Eddy
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is a combined observational and modeling study of eddy formation, growth, and export in the northwest corner region of the North Atlantic Current. The work will test the theory that eddy formation, growth, and capping is controlled by large heat fluxes between the ocean and atmosphere.

Intellectual Merit: The transition between the narrow boundary current and the broad eastward flow, often known as the Northwest Corner (NWC), provides a natural laboratory to study eddy dynamics because the process of eddy production is geographically localized, and highly repetitive. There is good reason to suspect that this process of eddy production and submergence may be a common and natural consequence of rapid heat loss along meandering sub-polar fronts. Indirect evidence for this may be seen in the high population of eddies in the ocean. Since these are known to continue to rotate and last for several years, it begs the question whether at least some of them could have originated from outcropping frontal regions of which there are many throughout the sub-polar oceans.

Broader Impacts: The work has the potential to transform the understanding of the ocean dynamics which are relevant to ocean-atmosphere exchanges in the North Atlantic. Climate ocean models typically do not represent well the northwest corner eddy region. If it turns out to be important for air-sea heat fluxes, it will highlight the need to improve these models, and may provide the dynamical understanding necessary to do so. With the assistance of the Office of Marine Programs through their ARMADA Project, a teacher will participate on each of the expeditions to gain research experience. The teachers will communicate this experience to both students at their school during the expedition and afterwards, in addition to mentoring a junior teacher on this research topic. This project will also provide training for one graduate student and enhance an international collaboration with Canadian scientists at the Bedford Institute of Oceanography who have research interests in this region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The oceans circulate water, heat and carbon around the planet, playing a key role in the earth's mass and energy balances. Changes in the ocean circulation likely influence climate change. The North Atlantic Current (NAC) brings warm water northward east of the Grand Banks and gives up heat to the atmosphere serving as a link in the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation, which is thought to play a key role in the Earth’s climate system. The NAC turns sharply to the right north of Flemish Cap in the region, known as the Northwest Corner (NWC), which has the curious property that it expands and expels pools of warm water on a quasi-regular basis, playing an important role in the air-sea heat exchange. These warm pools are dynamically active, forming warm-core eddies (large, swirling masses of seawater) which are able to trap and to transport water masses at large distances. Funding by NSF in this project allowed us to clarify physical mechanisms of eddy variability in the NWC and contributed to the understanding of processes likely not well represented in ocean models in a traditionally problematic region.

A field component of this project included four high resolution and two broader scale hydrographic surveys performed during two expeditions spanning a three-month period during Spring 2011. Results from these surveys were found to agree well with the output from the data assimilative HYCOM+NCODA Global 1/12 degree Analysis model (http://www.hycom.org) which has higher spatial/temporal resolution of the region than the surveys provided. Examples of the meridional and latitudinal transects in situ through a warm pool reveal the vertical structure of a warm-core eddy associated with a bump at the sea surface shown in the HYCOM output of image 1. Our major findings are that the warm-core eddies are persistent features in the NWC north of the Subpolar front; whereas their genesis and evolution are coupled with deep eddies (image 2) which are barely visible at the ocean surface.

A modeling component of this project included theoretical analysis and numerical simulations to explain how deep eddies were generated beneath idealized upper ocean jets and vortices. An expulsion of warm eddies together with their kinetic and potential energy from the NAC into the NWC was found to be related to the formation of counter-rotating deep eddies (image 3) predicted by an elegant thin-jet theory generalized for an upper layer turning jet. The elongation of an initially circular warm pool and the development of deep satellite eddies were shown to be typical for realistic model parameters as illustrated in image 4. The corresponding self-intensification of water rotation around the eddy center through the water column was consistent with the velocity structure of a real ocean eddy shown in image 2. Thus, our theoretical analysis and idealized numerical modeling clarified the vertical coupling revealed in these observations and data-assimilative models.
